BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Wind slabs in the high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies on extremely steep slopes and.

The new snow-covered wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2600 m, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. On the Main Alpine Ridge, in the Ortler Range and in the Ultental and in high Alpine regions the likelihood of avalanches is a little higher.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. In some regions 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a resilient melt-freeze crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 1500 m. Over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The new snow and wind slabs of the last two days can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are to be expected. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southeasterly directions, easily released wind slabs will form in the course of the day. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls such avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The covering of new snow is soft. Over a wide area new snow is lying on an icy crust. These weather conditions will bring about a gradual rise in the danger of dry avalanches in particular on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 0 to 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Thursday above approximately 1500 m. The wind will be moderate to strong at times in some regions. As a consequence of new snow and wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes large wind slabs formed especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude. These can be released by a single winter sport participant.
As a consequence of solar radiation dry and moist avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday above approximately 2000 m.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a resilient melt-freeze crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
Above approximately 2100 m a lot of snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow as well as the resulting wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs formed. They must be evaluated with care and prudence. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions light precipitation. The weather will be cold.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Along the border with Switzerland and adjacent to ridgelines the avalanche danger is one level higher.
In the last two days sometimes large wind slabs formed especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude. These can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases, especially on wind-loaded slopes. Even a small avalanche can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
As a consequence of solar radiation small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on rocky sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday above approximately 2000 m.
The moderate wind has transported the new snow. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a resilient melt-freeze crust.
Above approximately 2100 m a lot of snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls mostly small wind slabs formed. Caution is to be exercised in particular in extremely steep shady starting zones at high altitude. Even a small avalanche can sweep snow sport participants along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday above approximately 2000 m.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. There is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the wind slabs have increased in size on Tuesday.
The fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released, even by a single winter sport participant, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, in particular on very steep slopes.
Individual natural dry avalanches are possible, but they can reach medium size in some cases, especially on extremely steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Monday: The weather was cold. In some localities 0 to 5 cm of snow has fallen, in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.
The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The backcountry touring conditions are quite favourable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Wind slabs in the high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies on extremely steep slopes and.

The new snow-covered wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2600 m, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. On the Main Alpine Ridge, in the Ortler Range and in the Ultental and in high Alpine regions the likelihood of avalanches is a little higher.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. Up to 15 cm of snow will fall. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a resilient melt-freeze crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes deep wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Some fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
There is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the wind slabs have increased in size appreciably on Tuesday.
The fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released, even by a single winter sport participant, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, in particular on very steep slopes.
Individual natural dry avalanches are possible, but they can reach medium size in isolated cases, especially on extremely steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Monday: The weather was cold. In some localities 5 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The snowpack remains prone to triggering in some places. The backcountry touring conditions are mostly favourable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Wind slabs in the high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies on extremely steep slopes and.

The new snow-covered wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2600 m, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. On the Main Alpine Ridge, in the Ortler Range and in the Ultental and in high Alpine regions the likelihood of avalanches is a little higher.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. Up to 15 cm of snow will fall. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a resilient melt-freeze crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing settling of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Some fresh snow as well as the mostly small wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the snowfall individual dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. From the middle of the day a moderate danger of moist and wet snow slides will be encountered in some regions. Backcountry tours should be started and concluded early.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a slight weakening of the snowpack in particular in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of sharply falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days. Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects.
